trans-unit.source: Working with Node.js Modules
trans-unit.target: Working with Node.js Modules

trans-unit.source: Learn how to work with Node.js modules when using Azure Web Sites or Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to work with Node.js modules when using Azure Web Sites or Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: Using Node.js Modules with Azure applications
trans-unit.target: Using Node.js Modules with Azure applications

trans-unit.source: This document provides guidance on using Node.js modules with applications hosted on Azure.
trans-unit.target: This document provides guidance on using Node.js modules with applications hosted on Azure.

trans-unit.source: It provides guidance on ensuring that your application uses a specific version of module as well as using native modules with Azure.
trans-unit.target: It provides guidance on ensuring that your application uses a specific version of module as well as using native modules with Azure.

trans-unit.source: If you are already familiar with using Node.js modules, **package.json** and **npm-shrinkwrap.json** files, the following is a quick summary of what is discussed in this article:
trans-unit.target: If you are already familiar with using Node.js modules, **package.json** and **npm-shrinkwrap.json** files, the following is a quick summary of what is discussed in this article:

trans-unit.source: Azure Webites understand **package.json** and **npm-shrinkwrap.json** files and can install modules based on entries in these files.
trans-unit.target: Azure Webites understand **package.json** and **npm-shrinkwrap.json** files and can install modules based on entries in these files.

trans-unit.source: Azure Cloud Services expect all modules to be installed on the development environment, and the **node\_modules** directory to be included as part of the deployment package.
trans-unit.target: Azure Cloud Services expect all modules to be installed on the development environment, and the **node\_modules** directory to be included as part of the deployment package.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Virtual Machines are not discussed in this article, as the deployment experience in a VM will be dependent on the operating system hosted by the Virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Virtual Machines are not discussed in this article, as the deployment experience in a VM will be dependent on the operating system hosted by the Virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] It is possible to enable support for installing modules using **package.json** or **npm-shrinkwrap.json** files on Azure, however this requires customization of the default scripts used by Cloud Service projects.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] It is possible to enable support for installing modules using **package.json** or **npm-shrinkwrap.json** files on Azure, however this requires customization of the default scripts used by Cloud Service projects.

trans-unit.source: For an example of how to accomplish this, see [Azure Startup task to run npm install to avoid deploying node modules](http://nodeblog.azurewebsites.net/startup-task-to-run-npm-in-azure)
trans-unit.target: For an example of how to accomplish this, see [Azure Startup task to run npm install to avoid deploying node modules](http://nodeblog.azurewebsites.net/startup-task-to-run-npm-in-azure)

trans-unit.source: Node.js Modules
trans-unit.target: Node.js Modules

trans-unit.source: Modules are loadable JavaScript packages that provide specific functionality for your application.
trans-unit.target: Modules are loadable JavaScript packages that provide specific functionality for your application.

trans-unit.source: A module is usually installed using the **npm** command-line tool, however some (such as the http module) are provided as part of the core Node.js package.
trans-unit.target: A module is usually installed using the **npm** command-line tool, however some (such as the http module) are provided as part of the core Node.js package.

trans-unit.source: When modules are installed, they are stored in the **node\_modules** directory at the root of your application directory structure.
trans-unit.target: When modules are installed, they are stored in the **node\_modules** directory at the root of your application directory structure.

trans-unit.source: Each module within the **node\_modules** directory maintains its own **node\_modules** directory that contains any modules that it depend on, and this repeats again for every module all the way down the dependency chain.
trans-unit.target: Each module within the **node\_modules** directory maintains its own **node\_modules** directory that contains any modules that it depend on, and this repeats again for every module all the way down the dependency chain.

trans-unit.source: This allows each module installed to have its own version requirements for the modules it depends on, however it can result in quite a large directory structure.
trans-unit.target: This allows each module installed to have its own version requirements for the modules it depends on, however it can result in quite a large directory structure.

trans-unit.source: When deploying the **node\_modules** directory as part of your application, it will increase the size of the deployment compared to using a **package.json** or **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file; however, it does guarantee that the version of the modules used in production are the same as those used in development.
trans-unit.target: When deploying the **node\_modules** directory as part of your application, it will increase the size of the deployment compared to using a **package.json** or **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file; however, it does guarantee that the version of the modules used in production are the same as those used in development.

trans-unit.source: Native Modules
trans-unit.target: Native Modules

trans-unit.source: While most modules are simply plain-text JavaScript files, some modules are platform-specific binary images.
trans-unit.target: While most modules are simply plain-text JavaScript files, some modules are platform-specific binary images.

trans-unit.source: These modules are compiled at install time, usually by using Python and node-gyp.
trans-unit.target: These modules are compiled at install time, usually by using Python and node-gyp.

trans-unit.source: Since Azure Cloud Services rely on the **node\_modules** folder being deployed as part of the application, any native module included as part of the installed modules should work in a cloud service as long as it was installed and compiled on a Windows development system.
trans-unit.target: Since Azure Cloud Services rely on the **node\_modules** folder being deployed as part of the application, any native module included as part of the installed modules should work in a cloud service as long as it was installed and compiled on a Windows development system.

trans-unit.source: Azure Websites does not support all native modules and might fail at compiling those with very specific prerequisites.
trans-unit.target: Azure Websites does not support all native modules and might fail at compiling those with very specific prerequisites.

trans-unit.source: While some popular modules like MongoDB have optional native dependencies and work just fine without them, two workarounds proved successful with almost all native modules available today:
trans-unit.target: While some popular modules like MongoDB have optional native dependencies and work just fine without them, two workarounds proved successful with almost all native modules available today:

trans-unit.source: Run **npm install** on a Windows machine that has all the native module's prerequisites installed.
trans-unit.target: Run **npm install** on a Windows machine that has all the native module's prerequisites installed.

trans-unit.source: Then, deploy the created **node\_modules** folder as part of the application to Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: Then, deploy the created **node\_modules** folder as part of the application to Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: Azure Websites can be configured to execute custom bash or shell scripts during deployment, giving you the opportunity to execute custom commands and precisely configure the way **npm install** is being run.
trans-unit.target: Azure Websites can be configured to execute custom bash or shell scripts during deployment, giving you the opportunity to execute custom commands and precisely configure the way **npm install** is being run.

trans-unit.source: For a video showing how to do this, see [Custom Website Deployment Scripts with Kudu].
trans-unit.target: For a video showing how to do this, see [Custom Website Deployment Scripts with Kudu].

trans-unit.source: Using a package.json file
trans-unit.target: Using a package.json file

trans-unit.source: The **package.json** file is a way to specify the top level dependencies your application requires so that the hosting platform can install the dependencies, rather than requiring you to include the **node\_packages** folder as part of the deployment.
trans-unit.target: The **package.json** file is a way to specify the top level dependencies your application requires so that the hosting platform can install the dependencies, rather than requiring you to include the **node\_packages** folder as part of the deployment.

trans-unit.source: After the application has been deployed, the **npm install** command is used to parse the **package.json** file and install all the dependencies listed.
trans-unit.target: After the application has been deployed, the **npm install** command is used to parse the **package.json** file and install all the dependencies listed.

trans-unit.source: During development, you can use the **--save**, **--save-dev**, or **--save-optional** parameters when installing modules to add an entry for the module to your **package.json** file automatically.
trans-unit.target: During development, you can use the **--save**, **--save-dev**, or **--save-optional** parameters when installing modules to add an entry for the module to your **package.json** file automatically.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [npm-install](https://npmjs.org/doc/install.html).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [npm-install](https://npmjs.org/doc/install.html).

trans-unit.source: One potential problem with the **package.json** file is that it only specifies the version for top level dependencies.
trans-unit.target: One potential problem with the **package.json** file is that it only specifies the version for top level dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Each module installed may or may not specify the version of the modules it depends on, and so it is possible that you may end up with a different dependency chain than the one used in development.
trans-unit.target: Each module installed may or may not specify the version of the modules it depends on, and so it is possible that you may end up with a different dependency chain than the one used in development.

trans-unit.source: When deploying to an Azure Webite, if your package.json file references a native module you will see an error similar to the following when publishing the application using Git:
trans-unit.target: When deploying to an Azure Webite, if your package.json file references a native module you will see an error similar to the following when publishing the application using Git:

trans-unit.source: Using a npm-shrinkwrap.json file
trans-unit.target: Using a npm-shrinkwrap.json file

trans-unit.source: The **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file is an attempt to address the module versioning limitations of the **package.json** file.
trans-unit.target: The **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file is an attempt to address the module versioning limitations of the **package.json** file.

trans-unit.source: While the **package.json** file only includes versions for the top level modules, the **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file contains the version requirements for the full module dependency chain.
trans-unit.target: While the **package.json** file only includes versions for the top level modules, the **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file contains the version requirements for the full module dependency chain.

trans-unit.source: When your application is ready for production, you can lock-down version requirements and create an **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file by using the **npm shrinkwrap** command.
trans-unit.target: When your application is ready for production, you can lock-down version requirements and create an **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file by using the **npm shrinkwrap** command.

trans-unit.source: This will use the versions currently installed in the **node\_modules** folder, and record these to the **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file.
trans-unit.target: This will use the versions currently installed in the **node\_modules** folder, and record these to the **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file.

trans-unit.source: After the application has been deployed to the hosting environment, the **npm install** command is used to parse the **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file and install all the dependencies listed.
trans-unit.target: After the application has been deployed to the hosting environment, the **npm install** command is used to parse the **npm-shrinkwrap.json** file and install all the dependencies listed.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [npm-install](https://npmjs.org/doc/install.html).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [npm-install](https://npmjs.org/doc/install.html).

trans-unit.source: When deploying to an Azure Webite, if your npm-shrinkwrap.json file references a native module you will see an error similar to the following when publishing the application using Git:
trans-unit.target: When deploying to an Azure Webite, if your npm-shrinkwrap.json file references a native module you will see an error similar to the following when publishing the application using Git:

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you understand how to use Node.js modules with Azure, learn how to [specify the Node.js version], [build and deploy a Node.js Web Site], and [How to use the Azure Command-Line Interface for Mac and Linux].
trans-unit.target: Now that you understand how to use Node.js modules with Azure, learn how to [specify the Node.js version], [build and deploy a Node.js Web Site], and [How to use the Azure Command-Line Interface for Mac and Linux].

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
